data.title: Rounded Selection goes wrong when dragging

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.17.0
- OS Version: Windows 10 1709 insider slow 16299.15

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Turn on `"editor.roundedSelection"`
2. Write two lines of text, second line shorter then the first line
3. Double click and hold the mouse on the second line
   ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/22369305/31303380-343ee448-ab3f-11e7-84dd-77d80084b3d4.png)
4. Hold on, and drag up to the first line
   ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/22369305/31303357-c03c2dbc-ab3e-11e7-9fda-c9e0668a9dbf.png)
5. Hold on, and drag down back to the second line
   ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/22369305/31303359-dc2cef02-ab3e-11e7-9d3a-5e6b3e3aed28.png)
6. And the upper right corner of the rounded selection goes wrong.

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
- Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Won't open all previously opened windows when re-run the app.
data.body:
Sublime and other text editors are able to remember all previously opened windows when the app has exit and re-run again, only VS Code is doesn't. And It's almost 2018 bruh.

- VSCode Version: 1.17.0
- OS Version: macOS 10.13

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open two or more folders in two or more separate windows.
2. Exit VS Code.
3. Open VS Code once again will only open up a single window instead of all previously opened windows.

Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Return with increment operator breaks Typescript syntax highlight
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.17.0
- OS Version: Window 10 x64

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open a new empty Typescript file and paste the following:
```
setTimeout(function(){
  let c = 0;
  return c++ < 5;
},1);

let a = 10;
let b = function(){
  let everythingIsInGreenNow;
}
```
![](https://puu.sh/xRNZ9.png)


The syntax highlight is now broken for the rest of the file. The bug is only caused when the increment operator is used in the return statement. `return c-- < 5` does not cause the bug, only `return c++ < 5`;

Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Sort Lines Ascending command should use encoding ordering
data.body:
It's using a case-insensitive ordering, where all the "A"s are grouped together, then all the "B"s, and so on. As a programmer, this is such an odd choice. Uppercase letters are always ordered before lowercase letters, like with ASCII/UTF-8.

#### Steps to reproduce:

1. Enter this text:

```
a
B
```

2. Select both lines. Invoke the "Sort Lines Ascending" command.
3. Nothing changes.

Compare with `echo "a\nB" | sort`:

```
$ echo "a\nB" | sort
B
a
```

---

This pertains to the Sort Lines Descending command too, obviously.

I should add that the files in the file browser should be listed this way too, but aren't; they're listed in the case-insensitive way, which subverts the purpose of naming special files with uppercase letters, like Makefile and Dockerfile. If they're not listed first, then there's no point in using uppercase letters to name them.

---

- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---

data.title: VSCode window not given focus when invoking with -r from command line
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.17.0 (be377c0faf7574a59f84940f593a6849f12e4de7, 2017-10-04T23:45:46.804Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.15063
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
mssql|ms-|1.2.0
cpptools|ms-|0.13.1
csharp|ms-|1.12.1
rewrap|stk|1.5.1
vscode-terminal-here|Tyr|0.0.5



---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open VSCode 
2. With code command accessible in path, open either a PowerShell or Command window, and run:
3. code -r test.txt
4. Expected behavior is that the existing VSCode window will be activated / given focus.
5. Instead, the VSCode icon on the taskbar flashes orange, but the window is not activated, requiring an extra click to activate it.

This is annoying when trying to use VSCode as an editor for writing git or svn commit messages (i.e. when used as GIT_EDITOR or SVN_EDITOR).

As a workaround for now, I am able to use this code-focus.cmd file to activate the window before invoking VSCode:

`@echo off`
`echo (new ActiveXObject("WScript.Shell")).AppActivate("Visual Studio Code"); > %temp%\focus.js`
`cscript //nologo %temp%\focus.js`
`del %temp%\focus.js`
`code %*`

I can then invoke this file instead of VSCode in my GIT_EDITOR and SVN_EDITOR environment variables.

I've just started using VSCode for this purpose, so don't know if this behavior is new (due to either the Windows 10 Creator's Update or the September 2017 update to VSCode) or has always been this way.

May be related to: electron/electron#2867

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Fast path for quick open by filename
data.body:
I'm on Linux working with very large code trees over a network filesystem (~250,000 files, 200 GB). 

In this environment, the quick open command takes several minutes when first searching for a new file - presumably because it's looking across this entire, very large file system. Given the full feature set of quick-open, the slow performance makes sense - but I really need to solve the simpler subproblem of typing an exact filename (or even exact path) of a source file and getting it to open within say 5 sec (it currently takes 5 min). 

The subset of files I care about is small, and doesn't change often. I only need this to work for a limited set of extensions (ie, .cpp, .h. .py) and a limited subset of the filesystem where we store source files. It seems like this should be easy enough to handle with a small cache of source files scraped out of a larger tree...

Do I have any options for this with VS Code's current implementation?  I've already pruned some folders with file.excludes, but it doesn't seem to make a noticeable impact on performance. Since the editor is responsive after I've issued a query once, is there a way to write a script to prepopulate a cache with the files I care about?

I'm also willing to write my own extension, but I can't find a way take additional user input (ie a target filename) from the command palette - all the examples simply execute based on the name of the command. If this feature is easy to add, I'd happily do the legwork to build my own cached search over a limited database of relevant files.

Any help would be much appreciated!!

data.title: Weird Go To Implementation Command Palette behavior
data.body:
<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.17.0-insider 2017-10-3 commit 5316a2
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open/create a C# project with the following text (2 classes that implement an interface)
```C#
interface IA {}

class A : IA {}
class B : IA{} 
```
2. Place the caret on the definition of `IA`
3. Press F1 to open the command palette
4. Type "go to implementation" to bring up the go to implementation command

5a: click on the "go to implementation" entry in the drop down: a code peek view appears allowing you to choose between viewing A and B
5b: press enter to go to implementation: VSCode navigates directly to A without showing the code peek

If you look closely, you can see the code peek flicker into the screen. It looks like the "enter" is improperly getting passed into to code peek menu after it's shown, hence only clicking the command name shows you the menu.

data.title: Running MSBuild based build task hangs forever
data.body:
VSCode gets stuck when trying to build a simple C++ project (Visual C++ template console app) using the default build task (generated by the editor) with the terminal showing that it tries to execute MSBuild. The editor indicates that the command is running but the process explorer shows only one new `code.exe` process instance spawned and one of the existing earlier `code.exe` processes spinning excessively on `Code.exe!IsSandboxedProcess`, nothing else. Now I can't run any more build tasks and cannot stop the 'executing' one. To reset the situation I have to restart the editor.

- VSCode Version: 1.16
- OS Version: Windows 10 Professional x64

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create dummy C++ console app project in Visual C++
2. Open solution folder with `code .` (from visual studio developer prompt but no difference if normal `cmd.exe` is used)
3. Create default MSBuild build task in `tasks.json`
4. Execute build task (ctrl + shift + b)
5. Wait...

Reproduces without extensions: Yes

This is my current settings for **launch.json** file.
```
{
        "version": "0.2.0",
        "configurations": [
        {
            "type": "node",
            "request": "launch",
            "name": "Launch via NPM",
            "runtimeExecutable": "npm",
            "runtimeArgs": [
                "run-script",
                "debug"
            ],
            "port": 5858
        },
            {
                "type": "node",
                "request": "launch",
                "name": "Launch Program",
                "program": "${file}"
            }
        ]
    }
```
3. The debug console windows will open and output the message ```Debugging with inspector protocol because Node.js v8.6.0 was detected.```, but nothing else will run.

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

---

html-css-class-completion|Zig|1.10.0


---

## Steps to Reproduce:

1. In VSCode, create and fill a .md file (markdown).
2. Go offline (disconnect network cable and WiFi).
3. Open Markdown review on VSCode.
4. The preview windows opens, but nothing is displayed.


<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

## Developers Tools: Console Log

```
shell.ts:419 net::ERR_INTERNET_DISCONNECTED

Error: net::ERR_INTERNET_DISCONNECTED: Error: net::ERR_INTERNET_DISCONNECTED

Error: net::ERR_INTERNET_DISCONNECTED
    at Timeout._onTimeout (C:\Program Files\Microsoft VS Code\resources\app\out\vs\code\electron-main\main.js:4:78173)
    at ontimeout (timers.js:386:14)
    at tryOnTimeout (timers.js:250:5)
    at Timer.listOnTimeout (timers.js:214:5)
---
webview.ts:151 [Embedded Page] Uncaught Error: EFILE
```

generally issues: #35683 

- APP (Desktop, taskbar, start, context menu or files icons issues):

- [x] Old Icon, when you are not updating, but use new install (by installator from web) #35736

- [ ] The lack of visual distinctness with Sublime is not great. As noted on https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/6607#issuecomment-334792687. ... https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/35683#issuecomment-334831978
- [ ] Switching icon color? #35674 

- Website:
- [x] [website] favicon is not updated #35708

data.title: Removed files persisted in cache and displayed in search/quick open file results
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.17.0
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. create file `test1` with content `test`
2. create file `test2` with content `test`
3. search `test` and see both files in results
4. delete file `test2`
5. search `test` and see both files in results again

Also there is can be same issue with quck open files list, but i cant reproduce it again

Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Customizable status bar item locations
data.body:
Hello

It would be really nice if one could customize the location of the items in the status bar at the bottom of the editor.  For instance, I would want to have git branch information on the right, text encoding and position on the left, etc.

Maybe allow people to sort things with something like 
```javascript
"window.statusBar.items": {
    "left" : ["cursorPosition", "tabWidth"],
    "right": ["textEncoding", "gitBranch", "feedbackButton" ] 
}
```
